content:
Was following https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/propositions_and_proofs.html

#check Implies gives error saying unknown identifier 'Implies'. Did this get removed and now we have to use -> ?
it's in Mathlib, you just have to import it (or import a file that imports it)
oh wait, Proof isn't real, it's just a hypothetical

This chapter is a quick "what if we set things up this way".

Click the eyeball icons in the upper-right corners of the code blocks to see the hidden definitions.
The point of the discussion is that we don't need Implies p q since p → q is the same concept.

Matt Diamond said:

docs#Implies

Just did google search for "lean4 Implies" before posting here and got no links to this doc. Thanks for the pointer.

Moreover, once we make this identification, the rules for implication show that we can pass back and forth between Implies p q and p → q. In other words, implication between propositions p and q corresponds to having a function that takes any element of p to an element of q. As a result, the introduction of the connective Implies is entirely redundant: we can use the usual function space constructor p → q from dependent type theory as our notion of implication.
(You're not the first person to ask about this section. It should probably put this conclusion earlier so you're not confused about what Implies is and think it's something you've missed.)
I also should probably read the whole chapter before posting. But yeah if it was not hidden behind the eye, would have been less confused. Thanks for quick answer.
